ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also did breakout discussions and student presentations in class.
We would occasionally split into small virtual groups for more of a seminar style experience.
Imaging technology through zoom of Yales collection of Egyptian artifacts  very engaging and worked surprisingly well.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of background knowledge on magic that has helped me understand archaeological practices necessary for my major.
I gained a broader understanding of the role of magic in Ancient Egyptian, Mesopotamian, and early Islamic cultures as well as the intersection of magic, ritual, and religion in all three cultures.

I learned a great deal about magic in Egypt, Mesopotamia, and Islam. It was really interesting learning about the culture of each place and their definitions of magic. It was also great that we were able to see artifacts close up on the screen.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course worked well in the virtual format, and I particularly enjoyed the use of guest lecturers for different topics.

The course provides an excellent breadth of information and the inclusion of guest lecturers in the different areas is definitely a plus. In normal times the opportunity to view objects in the Babylonian collection in person would be an additional bonus. There could be a greater effort made to integrate the topics between the three main cultures of focus - perhaps organizing the course by type of magic or ritual and then discussing its use and applications in each of the three cultures.

A strength is that the professor was seemed to be really engaged and passionate about what he was teaching. I really appreciate the passion he showed when teaching the course. He was also really helpful when questions were asked or when emails were sent.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The way the class was set up as a mix of lecture and discussion allowed for greater engagement than some of my courses I took this year that were lecture only.

The virtual lectures were excellent, and the recordings were available although I never accessed them because my internet connection is not sufficient for playback on Panopto. I think there could have been more emphasis placed on in class discussion and student interaction early in the semester - the attempts at break out rooms late in the semester were awkward because no one was used to participating in class.

The lectures were recorded, which was good because I experienced internet problems during this class sometimes. We would also go into breakout rooms sometimes, which helped with engagement and participation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It is great for people that are in NELC or related majors, but its also extremely engaging regardless of your background or major.

Yes, unlike many other classes, student engagement and learning were at the top of the priority list for Prof Darnell. Not a class I was expecting to engage with as much as I ended up  very comfortable environment.

I would recommend this course *only* as an in-person course, because I feel the lectures would have been more engaging in person and the interaction with the artifacts would be much more meaningful in person as well.

I would recommend this course to a student who enjoys learning about magic within Egypt, Mesopotamia, and Islam. Since there are a lot of readings, they need to be interested in the subject to be able to learn about it properly. There are also quite a bit of writing assignments. If they want to take this course, they need to be prepared to read a lot and write quite a bit.
